TL;DR: The game's art and music is wonderful, but it doesn't particularly evolve upon the Impressions City Building Series formula. Maybe good for a player new to the series or one lapsed for a long time, but somewhat simple for series veterans.

Edit: All the major bugs I experienced in my initial review have since been fixed.

Lethis is a clear spiritual successor to the games of the Impressions City Building series (Caesar, Pharaoh, Zeus, and Emperor). All of the core mechanics of the series (housing evolution, random walkers, etc.) are here in their usual forms. You build housing, immigrants arrive, and you must supply the housing with food, goods, and services, causing it to evolve and support more workers. You must balance your treasury by importing and exporting goods, and by taxing your citizens. The game plays largely as expected of the series, with the only real surprise being a perplexing inversion of the standard mouse button functions (i.e. left click to examine a building instead of right), with no options that I could find to customize the controls.

The art style is excellent 2-D isometric, with a cartoony style that reminds me of the Ankama Studios games (Wakfu, Dofus, etc.). Walkers have both male and female versions for all the walkers I could see, which is a nice touch. I miss the voice-acted walker dialogue from the old games, but I understand the budgetary constaints that kept them out.The graphics are likely the only area in which Lethis markedly improves upon it's predeccessors.

My major complaints with the game are twofold: the relative simplicity of the game compared to its predeccessors, and the significant raft of launch bugs.

Mechanically, Lethis doesn't particularly add anything to the other entries in the Impressions City Building Series. The game's complexity is slightly above that of Zeus (in my opinion the simplest of the series), but without the military or mythological aspects (the latter of which was a major component of Zeus).

For the most part, quality of life features hover between Zeus and Emperor levels. Buildings can be toggled off individualy, like emperor. Roadblocks exist to limit random walkers, but not emperor's more selective smart" roadblocks. The one new feature

reviewText:
I'm sorry I can't recommend it. YET
I really wanted (and tried hard) to like this game. However there are certain reasons that made me stop playing it.

Unexpectedly quits quite often. Like every half an hour. And for such a small game it takes absurdly long to load on my ssd.

Unlike any other city building games, houses downgrade at the speed of light and once it does, the rest follows because everything in the chain of production gets ♥♥♥♥ed up. You insta loose, game over. Or you try hard to get back up. I am going to give an example how this ruins a game, skip the next paragraph if you don't want to read it.

Let's say a building has collapsed (you cannot imagine how often they collapse! And if you don't have a good memory, you won't even know what has collapsed because every ruin has the same texture). Imagine your 'well' has collapsed. This is a building you need for upgrading your houses to level 2. All your level 10 buildings (for which you had worked REALLY HARD  to build) will downgrade to level 1. This will have a HUGE impact on your population. Within seconds many people will leave your city. Your buildings will stop functioning because of worker shortage. You will try to save the moment by pausing the game. You have 2 options. You either go back to the autosave or if you are no quitter, you try.
You disable all production buildings 1-by-1 so that your workers will work at the service buildings. This is to ensure that your other houses won't downgrade too. If you had stocked all kinds of products that are needed by your people, this may work. (If you didn't, you better try the autosave because you are ♥♥♥♥ed.) So anyway, your houses will slowly upgrade, you will get your people back. After 20 minutes of trying hard, stress and anger; you get back to where you were. And as soon as you feel the joy of rescuing your city from going down, don't worry the game goes down. Quits unexpectedly. You reopen the game and use the autosave.

The 3rd reason is the 2nd reason again!! This is way too important guys. This game is about levelling up your buildings. You might play for 4 hours and loose all the progress because some delivery guy randomly decided to walk another road and the buildings on that street couldn't get their laundry done, just for ONCE.  They will punish you for it. They will abandon your settlement. You can have 40% unemployment and they will keep coming to the city. But if they can't get what they need just for once. Oh they are on their way out bro..
This game could be really fun to play and I would have recommended it if these problems didn't exist. After hours of stubbornly trying to make the game work, I am giving up. I won't be playing it anymore. I will track the updates and revise this review if they ever change things.

PS Since most people are getting this wrong, I felt the need to add here that the main problem isn't the collapsing buildings, it's how fast the buildings level down as a response to the things happening. Collapse was just an example..

Updates to this Review
Devs would like us to consider the game as early access, and they are promising updates (especially for crashes). And they have a list of known bugs.

Clicking on ruins now gives information on the building that collapsed.     I have to admit that this is the kind of a game I've missed a lot. I really enjoy the genre and the graphics are pleasent. I would change this review to recommended as soon as it really is recommendable

It's been said that many crashes have been fixed. I didn't have time to test the last patch (3rd of july) yet but the developers are working hard every day and pushing many updates. I am looking forward to change this review to recommended.  (After saying this I tried playing again and had a good run for about 30mins until the game crashed again unfortunately..)
VERDICT:
It is your decision if you are up to a fight with the mechanics I have mentioned above. It is manegeable with a more conservative gameplay. You can develop your own strategies and beat the part of the mechanics that I personally dislike. However the game at its current state prohibits you from doing that. It crashes. A lot. Don't buy it before they fix it. It is really tempering when it crashes all the time.

My recommendation is add this game to your wishlist and check back often. Because the pace of updates is fast and I am looking forward to see this game become an awesome one real soon.

reviewText:
I could tell you of how this game is a solid City Builder in vein of Impressions Games' Titles such as Casesar III, Pharaoh and Zeus. I could tell you of the variety of buildings in the game with an absolute 'motherlode' of content that would have any fan of City Builders to dig up a copy of SimCity IV. However, that's not what made me really like this game. It was the aesthetic, the freaking epic soundtrack that immerses you in the eventually complicated webs of services, residential zones and beautification monuments. Your bustling city full of working citizens from supernatural exorcists to copper miners and shopkeepers. An artstyle that screams originality and further draws you in to this Steam Punk world of industrialized Urban centers. Faes sparkle in the woods outside your city, water pours from pipes jutting out of the edges of the known world while steam bellows from the chasms of magma bellow the surface. Life, though artificial, is mostly certainly alive here. And undoubtedly, that's the best feature I've found in my time with Lethis.
Now that's not to say the game is perfect. You notice very quickly that the soundtrack is the most prevalent noise in the game as sound effects only cue when you click on buildings or citizens. It's eerie that so much activity is occuring in your city but you could hear a pin drop if the music was muted. Personally, I would've appreciated there to be voice actors in the game... not annoying voices that talk every five seconds but rather, Pharaoh's approach or Stronghold where citizens would recite lines of how well their lives are going in game. A minor request, for sure, but it sure would bring a human element to this otherwise lively, bustling world.
All in all, this game is well worth 20 bucks and I can see myself pouring dozens if not hundreds of hours into perfecting my little Victorianesque Steam Punk cities.

reviewText:
If you never played Impressions Games’ Pharao, Caesar or Emperor, grab this game at once!
If you did play them, don't expect anything new. At all.

PROS:
- It looks amazing. The style is really cute, the animations are well done and the details are charming. Most walkers come in both genders which is a nice touch.

- The interface is much better than the Impressions games, aesthetically and in terms of layout. Showing the range of all walkers is really, really helpful in planning the city.

- It plays just like Impressions City Building Series.

CONS:
- It plays almost EXACTLY like Impressions City Building Series. I guess you can't do much wrong when you copy a good game (series). But aside from one or two production chains, you have to admit, it's really just a clone with a different skin. It’s actually easier than some of its spiritual predecessors.

- Steam should have played a bigger part. This is the only thing that's different from the Impressions games and there should be many more buildings that need steam. It would be a big step to set Lethis apart from the games it copies. Same with automatons. So much potential wasted…

- The statistics are only accessible when you build a town-hall, much like Banished did it, which is mostly okay. But worker distribution priorities should not be accessible through a window that’s only available when a certain building has workers. If you set the administration priority too low, your town-hall will stop working and you suddenly lose access to that window and then you have to deactivate your entire economy manually just so your town-hall has enough workers and you can change things back.

- The game does not warn you when you are about to quit the session and it doesn’t remind you of saving. If you click quit and you haven’t saved you will lose all your progress. Which is really irritating when you accidently clicked quit instead of resume.

- What are those trees that I cannot remove? Not the unique looking ones, those are cool, but plain old trees that you simply cannot remove. What’s up with that, Triskell?

- There should be more information about a building BEFORE you build it as it isn’t obvious what some of these buildings do. It would be nice if the tooltips showed more than just the price.

- Tooltips are annoyingly slow.

As someone who played the Impressions City Building Series, this game had nothing new to me. The only things I had to figure out were steam and automatons, which are both nice ideas but not developed enough, in my opinion.

Still recommending this game because it’s fun and gorgeous. But sadly, nothing new.

reviewText:
As far as I know, I've never really played any city builders before, or at least, didn't enjoy them enough to remember them. Figured this one might end up the same way, but thankfully it hasn't.
I'm really, really enjoying this game so far.
The art is wonderful; the designs are charming and eye-catching, very creative, especially the characters, and I'm really liking all the detail put into everything. And the music! It's very light-hearted and fun, but it's also very fitting and not at all distracting. I thought the little details - the use of the French Republican Calendar, the references, sound effects, etc.- were all pretty neat, too, and personally I think stuff like that makes the game even more fun, makes it more appealing when there's extra stuff to catch your attention.

I thought the tutorial, for the most part, was easy enough to follow and helped me understand the game much better -isn't that what a good tutorial is meant to do, though?-, especially as someone who has never played any city builders before. There was some stuff I struggled to understand at first, particularly in the last two chapters of the tutorial, and some parts seemed to progress a little slower than I'd have liked, but maybe that was just me being a novice, ha! I do wish I could have had a way to repeat some of the instructional dialogue, but maybe there is and I just missed it? If not, it'd be nice to have that just in case someone else is like me and clicks too fast.

There were a few minor problems I had, but nothing major at all. The game crashed a few times on my older laptop, but once I put it on the newer one it's worked just fine so far. It seems to freeze when you select certain options (loading a chapter or a saved file, etc.), but then it works just fine after. Not a problem, but it can get just a little annoying. So far, I haven't had any problems in-game, just a few minor annoyances mostly related to me just being impatient or not understanding something clearly enough.
It's been pointed out before, but there could also be a bit more proof-reading with the translation. Personally, I didn't find the errors that bothersome or noticeable, but it did sometimes make it a little difficult to properly understand the instructions they gave you, especially during the latter half of the tutorial. I also didn't mind the few stray bits of text that were left in French.

There are things that could be fixed or improved, sure -and the team is working on it, this game is frequently updated!-, and some parts are a little slow, at least, for me, but I'm not used to the pacing of city builders, yet. But, the art style is great, the game is very colorful and visually appealing, the text -even if it's not quite translated right-, is charming and to me it seems pretty fitting to the era the game is supposed to be in. Some of the tasks are fun and challenging, and I like that little rush I get when I've done something right, even more-so when I'm rewarded with a nifty little achievement!
I also really, really appreciate the fact that the game's creators are very involved in the discussions and forums, that they answer all your questions and critiques honestly and are willing to listen to complaints and find ways to solve them. From the looks of it, it seems like they're working really hard to get all the bugs and kinks worked out, translation errors included. :>

It's my first real adventure into a city builder game, and so far I'm really starting to like the genre. I'd definitely recommend Lethis, especially once it's gotten most of the bugs smoothed out.

This game is a spiritual sucessor of the Pharaoh/Cleopatra/Caesar/Zeus/Poseidon and Emperor from Impression Games.
That said, it has the same core mechanics.

Graphics: are AMAZING,  the game is h pretty, animation too.

Sound: beutiful soundtrack and when you click in buildings there is also sounds for each of them. There is no background sound yet, but Devs said that will be added soon, so I might update the review

Interface: Most of the interface is intuitive, there is tabs for each production chain and services. There is also graphics and most of the time you dont need many clicks to get what you want to see.

Tutorial: Its good enough for teaching the basics BUT it does not provide players in depth explanation to some core important aspects of the games and how to use it - Walkers and roadblocks.

Overal gameplay: The game is fun, no doubt of that. There is no combat (donno if there will be) but the management city building thingy is good and can be challenging in Hard mode. There is a happiness system that takes place and its important to the city. If taxes are too high and payment too low they will riot, no food they leave etc etc..

CORE Mechanics:
Production: If you need cooper, you need to build cooper mine right? If you need potato, build a potato farm. That is the basic production. The citzens have needs for food, drinks and services like theater, papernews kiosk etc. The production is intuitive and easy. To make bread you going to need to build a wheat farm, then a Wildmill and finally a bakery. There is plenty of resources to explore and a Steam system that is quite nice and fit the steampunk nature of the game

Delivery: After the production, your citzens are going to need buildings to deliver the goods to them. A shop will deliver food and drinks. The storehouse will deliver the goods needed to the production facilitys. The delivery system is a core mechanic because if you place buildings far from the material needed it will decrease the production because of the time the walker needs to get there.

Walkers: Its the old impression game style of city building mechanic. Each service or production building has a Walker (little person who walks arround the city) to delivery the services/goods to the houses. When they pass in front of the house, the service is provided and the walker need to constant pass that location from time to time to deliver the service again or the house will no longer get the service.

Roadblock: This is one of the most important little thing that you need to understand. This will block the passage of the walker, so you limit the area that the walker will deliver the service. When you do that, you start to see that you need to use this often so you can create neighbourhoods with all the services. The roadblock only block the walkers to go to another area to provide the service, it will not block the walker from taking any goods that he needs to provide the service to the houses. Example: Shop/food walker wont pass the roadblock to delvier food but will pass the roadblock to pick up food from the granary.

Updrading Houses: There is 10 lvls of houses. Each lvl demands a type of good to be delivered so the house can lvl up to the next lvl. That is why sometimes you going to need 2 types of food for example, or you going to need garments for elite houses, or alchool etc etc.Each lvl can acomodate more people and generate more taxes for you :)

This game has a campaing and a sandbox mode. Both are fun in their own ways.
I recomend the game, ITS ADCTING. If  you played old impression games you will be at home.
IF not, you can play one of the most adcting city builders that is.

tl;dr: Good Impressions-like city builder with lacking end game.

Lethis - Path of Progress is a city builder in the style of the classic games by Impressions (Zeus, Pharaoh, Caesar). If you have played any of those games before, you will feel immediately hat home: The gameplay is basically the same, build places for houses and buildings to satisfy the inhabitants' needs. Workes patrol the streets and refresh stocks of food, bring them water or exorcise ghosts from the houses. Upperclass citizens life in masions and to not interact with the common folk but steam-powered automatons instead.
Industry is pretty standard with rather short production chains, the classic farm-mill-bakery is one of the longest. Steam is a special ressource, as some buildings require direct connection to steam pipes, while others use it bottled. Excess ressoures can be traded with other cities.
The game is very competend at what is does, which is building a city. It lacks advanced mechanics like a military or others, like the pan-hellenic games in Zeus. After about half of the 26-mission campaign I felt like i saw everything, there were no new buildings and the mission goals are reather similar: build a city with x citizens in houses of level y, build a monument, gather z amout of ressources. Since you have to start with an empty map everytime makes the early stages rather boring after a while. The game is in general very relaxed, as there are no timelimits in any mission.
THe Story is somewhat forgettable and only told in text messages. The gaphics is very nice, very detailled 2d comic graphics with exceptionally detailed animations. The music is fitting and somewhat whimsical, strengthening the relaxed and not to serios athmosphere of the game.
Nontheless, it is a good game since the developers focused on the aspect of building a city which the games does well. I hope they take this good foundation and build a sequel with more  advanced mechanics, keeping the motivation up  in later stages of the game.

Game Details

Published by: Triskell Interactive
Developed by: Triskell Interactive
Genre: Indie, Simulation, Strategy
Release Date: 25 June 2015
Completionist Gameplay: 50+ Hours

Lethis- Path of Progress is a Victorian steam punk city management strategy game with an amazingly addictive art style. The art alone throughout this game is so aesthetically pleasing and wonderful to look at that you’ll play this game solely to experience it. That said, there are multiple other reasons why you’ll play this game. It has a magical soundtrack that will get you singing along for days on end while somehow not ever managing to get sick of it and the game-play is quite addictive itself. There’s even a sandbox mode for you to build the city of your dreams!

The game-play requires you to meet a goal before you can pass a level. Essentially, you’re trying to keep your citizens happy by supplying them with food, water, bathing houses, utensils, culture and medicine. You must build farms, neighborhoods, factories, storage buildings and pay for these with the taxes that you collect from your citizens. If your city becomes developed enough, you can build mansions and shops for the upper class. However, the upper citizens refuse to be served by real humans, so you’ll need to build entirely new factories to build automations, and to build those factories you’ll need more middle class, and for more middle class you’ll need more food! It’s very fun to juggle all of these factors and just scrape past into a win. As you fulfill your citizens needs and wants you’ll level up the buildings that they live in and increase the amount of citizens that can live in them and it’s one of the most satisfying feelings in game. Be careful though, you’ll need to make sure you don’t move in too many people at once or the demand will be less than the supply!

The game-play seems to last forever and there is a steep difficulty curve. Whether or not that is a positive for you, it is something to consider. Personally, I loved that it challenged me and wasn’t as easy as many other city management games. There was no hand-holding or obvious hints or tips and the game leaves the player to figure it out themselves. I spent maybe three hours and countless resets trying to get past the first tutorial level. However, once you get the hang of the game it becomes very easy as the later levels do not introduce any new game play tactics.

Overall, I would absolutely recommend this game for anyone who is a fan of city management strategy games. I would also recommend this game to everyone else as the art style and soundtrack is next level awesome.

Where to begin... It's beautiful! The art direction is fantastic, the style is really appealing and especially the animations are stunning - The little foxes hiding behind trees, the faes around the mushrooms, the steam condensor, even the dust whirling around once you build something.
It's full of life everywhere. Each time you look at something, it moves and you can't stop examining every little detail.
And I really love steampunk! The music is really good as well, it's uplifting and fitting the game perfectly! Even though there are some sounds missing still, many of them made me laught , especially the ranch's sound!

But let's talk about gameplay. I like it, it's cool and you have plenty to do – there's always something to build or to improve. You can spend hours building your perfect city, and optimizing your layout. You have many possibilities, there are 5 kinds of food, there even are wonders as for example in Pharaon at the time.

Also, each population has it's own needs, the rich people want jewellery, the poor want cutlery, everybody loving production chains will be satisfied (Raw materials, stockage, transformation, distribution and so on). You feel the game was inspired by Sierra's titles, and the building layouts are similar: maintenance is superimportant, and there even are ghosts! You need to carefully plan your cities, because one loose joint may make everything very difficult. So, there really is always something to do!

On a technical standpoint, the game is fine. You can always look at stastistics via that little eye button, or the full one, once you've built a townhall. They come in handy for people that want to build THE perfect city, but you do not absolutely have to look at it to win the game.

And  finally, I love the little annotations and the humour! There is a short text for every building or person, often with some pop-references that are genuinely funny.

Really, get it! Really! The content is amazing compared to for example Banished, where you only have 3 things to do in like 10 hours. Since they both cost the same, and the programmers will patch add new content to Lethis, this game has the potential to become gigantic!

P.S: For all people who experienced bugs, I haven't encountered a single one yet, perhaps they have been fixed already. - Decent mechanics (can put down roadblocks to prevent certain distributors from travelling excess amount of roads)

reviewText:
Okay. Let's begin the review. This is a honest summary of my experience so far with Lethis.

1) Gameplay

The game plays like a city builder should. You construct your city in whatever manner you seem fitting, you rotate buildings, you position infrastructure and decoration as you wish to.  There are bugs, but i will let them slide as this is the teams first title and most importantly, a fairly decent experience that they are willing to improve upon.

It seems like it might get very advanced and have a greater sense of depth to it. I am only 4 hours or so in however, but i have witnessed the ability to grow my cities by levelling up the housing for families (which requires me to provide for their cares, be it alcohol, washing facilities, food supplies or jobs). There is also maintanence, which means buildings can collapse unless you have a maintanence man checking in on them regularly. This is just a small part of the picture, you can build a lot of cool things to play around with.

There is a lot of intricacy, certain buildings require certain resources to run properly which means developing a well thought out road structure so your stockpiles of resources get distributed to the proper places.

i am sure a lot more will be coming.

2) Graphics

Oh the graphics. They are awesome. At a glance it looks pixel, zoom out all the way and it looks like im playing sim city or OTTD with a steampunk theme (which is fine, by the way) but then I found out i can zoom in all the way and look at what everybody in my city is doing.

Thats right. EVERYTHING is animated. I was amazed to watch the fishery after catching a fish, a giant fish is inside the building and the fisherman cuts meat from the fish and places it on a table. Then, a worker from the storage facility arrives and takes the fish in his cart (which is animated) to the facility and wham, now I can see fish stored in the crates. Your workers move to and fro, when a building is fully staffed there are animations and effects that play but its not just buildings. Environment is also animated!

Build a flower garden, watch as butterflys take up home. Build trees, and see birds flying about. In the wilderness itself, there are a combination of birds, foxes and rabbits if you look carefully enough they will peek out and dart around the map.

3) Sound.

The game has a lovely musical track which is very fitting to the theme and pleasent to listen to. A lot of the buildings have little sound effects when near them and when you click on them, as does the scenery. This is a very nice touch and i hope they expand upon it.

Now, the downsides:

1) Bugs - There are a lot of bugs, i am told. So far I have only encountered a crashing problem, other than that none but the forums suggest there are many so we shall see.

2) Interface - Its a little clunky at times, especially when rotating buildings. It's not always clear what side a building needs a road connected to function properly.

3) No control over worker routes - Currently you have no control over your workers routes directly. Workers will go work where they wish to work, they will walk randomly about the city to their establishments and this does pose a problem with supply. If your shop is constantly picking up the wrong product and sending it out to the wrong place for instance, its very difficult to figure out how to get around that problem without moving the shop itself.

You can place roadblocks which stop workers from passing through, so perhaps creative use of roadblocks is going to be the way forwards past that.

4) No control over workers in buildings - You simply have an on or off switch. You cannot assign workers to the buildings you wish them to go to. This currently forces you to construct more housing to fill any gaps. Not sure if this was intented or not.


Overall?

A great game that needs some more work. I highly reccomend supporting the dev team as it is currently playable and lovely to experience.  I am a huge fan of city builders as a concept, but i have only really played ANNO for a lengthy period of time but Lethis has become a personal favorite.  So what are you wating for, like steampunk and city building? Buy it, buy it now!

reviewText:
Overall the game is interesting, even fun. It's definitely a different take on city building. More basic in some respects and more difficult in others.
On to the postives: It looks a lot better playing it than it does in the pictures in the store. The music is great, the characters are adorable, and the campaign is fun and challenging at times. Housing is almost set up like neighborhoods, with each neighborhood needing to be served by different services in an efficient manner. The use of roadblocks keeps these services running in small ecosystems and keeps things moving smoothly. It's fun to watch roads and buildings upgrade as you have more affluent citizens move in.
The cons: My biggest con so far is that even with having a proprietary card the game eventually crashed. I'm hoping that this is not a recurring thing, otherwise the game is useless. As for gameplay: the buildings are neat and well-designed but there only seems to be one or two designs for each home and once they all upgrade they sort of just look the same. The neighborhoods are a neat concept but it leads to your city looking a bit disjointed. If you try making the neighborhoods into any other shape than a rectangle, your services may become inefficient. You also HAVE to use roadblocks or your services will try to walk the whole city, or at least as far as they can go, which doesn't provide great service. It's not the best game if you are a person who loves aesthetics when city building. Also, there are two classes of citizens: the regular poor folk who grow into the middle class, and the super rich. This is fine, but also kind of annoying for a few reasons.
One, your workers (the poor) will grow into housing that basically looks like a brownstone and that's it. Nothing super fancy or neat looking. Secondly, the rich are available right from the beginning. While this is neat and can help you balance your checkbook more easily, there isn't really a sense of achievement in attaining them. They also have completely separate buildings from the workers, meaning you don't have to really coordinate or juggle supplies efficiently to achieve anything, and they don't leave completely when their needs aren't met.
Overall, the game is good. I would recommend it to anyone fond of city-builders or resource management games. It's one of the easier games I've played in this genre. The art is good, the music is good, and the neighborhood concept is new and interesting. Anyone who is a fan of steampunk will at least like the art. That being said, the game does have a few shortfalls that may make it hard to keep replaying it, and those things might be the things that makes the game unique.

It’s been far too long since Impressions Games disappeared, and with it, such classics as Pharaoh, Zeus, and Emperor: Rise of the Middle Kingdom. From the beautiful art style reminiscent of a westernized Hayao Miyazaki (think Spirited Away) to the airy orchestral marches that accompany your reign as imperial city manager, Lethis is a peaceful city-builder whose 26 scenarios are as fun, challenging, and engaging as they are breathtaking to look at–which is quite a bit.

This game plays like a variation on the Pharaoh and Caesar games, reworked as a sort of economic puzzle game. It has the usual goods production sequences and housing upgrades, but all the services are delivered by road and in person, so from the start you need to be considering road layouts and sectioning manageable areas of housing. And then there's the art. The screenshots really don't do justice to the wonderfully detailed and animated towns you build. I get a real sense of pride in my bustling little metropolis when everything is working properly, since there's so much visual feedback from buildings and services as they go about their work.

There are a few issues that I have - it's not always visually apparent if a building is idle or working, and the localisation can be a bit wonky. My only really substantive criticism so far, though,  is some very occasional stability problems, but then I am playing immediately after release, and apparently fixes are in the works.

I can't say how much longevity it will have - the full variety of buildings is pretty quickly filled out, and so the later stages may have to rely more on the puzzle aspect of setting interesting and challenging missions, but so far I'm happy to own this game.

reviewText:
Harkening back to the golden age of the Impressions city builder titles (Pharaoh, Caesar 3, Zeus and Emperor) Lethis is able to proudly take its place among them. This game doesn’t aim to innovate on the genre- no- it does the opposite. It takes the old impressions formula and adapts it to a brand new theme... Now you may be thinking to yourself “that sounds terrible, why is this a positive review?” and if that is what you are thinking right now then likely you just don’t understand what exactly made these games magical. Fans of this series have been dreaming of the day when we would finally find another 2D title/developer capable of taking the torch and running with it... while Lethis is not perfect (I will come to my current issues with it soon) it certainly does do exactly what it says on the tin.
Lethis is comprised of a comprehensive (albeit buggy) campaign, a number of sandbox maps and a decently sized series of economic chains all with a focus on steampunk aesthetic. It has wonderful soundtrack and art to support the setting in a colourful way. You will see your small plebs squishing fae, cutting giant fish, washing massive silk worms and more. While the game does not have voice acted plebs like the impressions titles did, it does boast an impressive array of walker sprites which add variety to the game immensely. The only thing which is really cutting away at the immersion is the huge number of spelling and translation mistakes- but this can be easily forgiven when you realise that the developer is not a native speaker and they will likely be fixed over time.
The largest problems with Lethis in its current state are mostly found in the early game- but could likely be tweaked away. Food production seems too low for the amount consumed but industry production seems far far too HIGH. Covering a district in walkers often requires far too many buildings because the decay rate between building stages upon losing access to things seems far too fast. Someone doesn’t walk past for a few? Well- suddenly your entire district will go down three levels in a blink of an eye. The large maps are great and all, but with how quick houses can devolve that is counter-productive. One massive swarm of people leaving can often meet another swam of people coming to replace them... That seems screwy to me.
All and all though, the good far outweighs the bad and the game more than manages to scratch the itch left post Impressions. If you love these kinds of games chances are you will love this one too. If you didn’t love them though I doubt there would be much (if anything) here that would interest you.
